item.title: 2025 CTCF Club League
item.description:
The 2025 CTCF Club League is Cape Town’s premier team chess competition, bringing together the region’s strongest clubs in an 11-round tournament played over three months. The league showcases both established masters and rising talents, fostering competitive spirit and community among local players. With the season still underway, every round remains crucial as teams battle for top honors and bragging rights in one of South Africa’s most prestigious club events.

item.title: 2024 Steinitz Festival
item.description: The 47th anniversary Steinitz Chess Festival took place at Fairbairn College, Goodwood. 250 players participated with various Junior age groups, rapid sections, Fide rated sections. Players came from as far afield as Namibia, KZN and Mossel Bay, Overberg.

item.title: 2024 Club Championship
item.description: The 2024 Annual Steinitz Chess Club Championship took place in Cape Town on Saturday, April 13th, 2024. The event featured six rounds played at a rapid time control of 20 minutes plus a 5-second increment per move. Bringing together a strong field of club members, the championship provided an exciting day of competitive chess, highlighting both seasoned players and rising stars within the Steinitz community.

item.title: 2024 SA Senior Closed
item.description: The 2024 SA Senior Closed at the iconic Newlands venue was a fiercely contested and well-organized event, ending with Dr Lyndon Bouah and FM Shabier Bhawoodien sharing the senior title in a fitting display of competitive balance and sporting tradition.

item.title: 2022 CTCF Club League
item.description: Congratulations to our Steinitz A-team for winning the Premier Division of the 2022 Chess WP Club League Championship! We also congratulate Kraaifontein (winners of B Division), Capablanca (winners of C Division) and Delft (winners of D Division).

item.title: Reflections on the 2019 Cape Town Club League
item.description:
Reflections on Steinitz in the WP League

When I look back at the 2019 Western Province League, I feel immense pride in what Steinitz Chess Club has achieved. Over the course of that season, we played 11 matches, winning 10 and drawing just one — against a strong MRL side. Not once did we taste defeat. That kind of consistency doesn’t happen by accident. It reflects years of teamwork, preparation, and commitment.

item.title: 2014 AfriClub Champs
item.description: In March 2014, Cape Town proudly hosted the prestigious African Club Chess Championship at the Sun Hotel. The event brought together top club teams from across the continent, showcasing Africa’s finest chess talent in a spirit of competition and camaraderie. Players battled over the boards in a festival of strategy and skill, while the Mother City provided a fitting backdrop with its vibrant culture and iconic scenery. The tournament not only highlighted the growing strength of African chess but also reinforced Cape Town’s reputation as a hub for international sporting events.

item.title: Alex Akemdien
item.description: Alex Akemdien is a rising talent in the chess world, known for his sharp tactical vision and calm approach under pressure. He began playing chess at a young age and quickly distinguished himself on the local circuit, earning recognition for his rapid improvement and consistent performances against seasoned opponents. Over the years, Alex has represented his club in multiple regional and national tournaments, where he has delivered notable results on top boards. His ability to combine creative attacking play with solid strategic understanding has made him a formidable competitor. Beyond individual accolades, Alex has contributed significantly to his team’s success, helping secure podium finishes in league competitions. Dedicated to continual growth, he studies classical games and modern opening theory with equal enthusiasm, ensuring his style remains both dynamic and adaptable. With his ambition and discipline, Alex Akemdien is steadily building a reputation as one of the promising chess players to watch in the coming years.

item.title: Andrew Talmarkes
item.description: Andrew Talmarkes is an accomplished chess coach, FIDE-licensed arbiter, and long-time leader within Cape Town’s Steinitz Chess Club. He is the Director of the Insight Chess Academy, providing specialized individual and group coaching—including tailored sessions for clients with ADHD or focus challenges. A pillar in chess administration, he has served in numerous key roles: tournament director, deputy chief arbiter at the 2024 Cape Town Masters Challenge, and fixture within the CHESSA arbiter program as well as the Western Province youth coaching scene. Awarded the Community Builder Award in 2013 for his work on Mitchell’s Plain Chess Development and Library Project, Talmarkes continues to shape youth and community chess.

item.title: Benjamin Dubbeld
item.description: Benjamin Dubbeld is a promising young chess player from Cape Town. Introduced to competitive chess in grade 8 at Westerford High School in 2023, he quickly developed a love for the game and began participating in local tournaments in 2024. Now in grade 10, Benjamin is a key member of his school’s first team, contributing to their successes in interschool competitions. His strong performances have earned him selection for the Western Province Under-18 team, which will compete in Gqeberha in December. Benjamin combines a strategic approach with keen tactical awareness, showing steady growth as he gains experience in both school and regional competitions. He is widely regarded as one of the rising talents in Western Province chess.

item.title: Callum Lau
item.description: Callum Lau is an emerging talent in Cape Town and active member of Steinitz Chess Club. In 2025 Callum achieved 3rd Place in the Western Cape Schools Chess High School Individual Provincial Championship, Representing Rondebosch Boys’ High School. His outstanding performance among the province’s top young chess talents earned him a coveted spot at the National Championships, where he will represent the Western Cape at the highest level of school chess competition in South Africa.

item.title: Clinton Solomon
item.description: Clinton Solomon is a passionate chess organizer, mentor, and advocate for youth chess in Cape Town. As the Youth Director of Steinitz Chess Club, he works tirelessly to create opportunities for young players, providing access to quality coaching, structured tournaments, and a supportive community. Since 2019, Clinton has traveled extensively across South Africa with his son, Izaiah Solomon—one of the region’s most promising young chess talents—attending both Federation and school chess tournaments. These experiences have given him a deep understanding of the needs and challenges facing youth chess players.

item.title: Colin Webber
item.description: Colin Webber is an active member of the Cape Town chess community, balancing his own journey as an “adult improver” with his passion for supporting the game. A former chess parent—his son Ethan no longer plays competitively—Colin has stayed deeply connected to the sport through both playing and service. He currently serves as the Technical Officer and Webmaster of Steinitz Chess Club, where he helps manage the club’s digital presence and supports its ongoing growth. Alongside his technical contributions, Colin enjoys encouraging and mentoring young players, drawing on his experiences as both a parent and competitor. His enthusiasm for lifelong learning and his commitment to fostering talent make him a valuable part of the Steinitz family.

item.description: Curtis Gal discovered chess in primary school and quickly developed a passion for the game. item.title: Declan Platen
item.description: Declan Platen is a respected player, coach, and leader within the Steinitz Chess Club, where he currently serves as Club Captain. Known for his steady play and deep understanding of the game, Declan has represented Steinitz in league competitions and other events, contributing both on and off the board. As a coach, he is dedicated to nurturing young talent, sharing his knowledge and experience to help players sharpen their skills and build confidence. His approachable teaching style and passion for chess make him a role model for many up-and-coming players in the Western Cape. In his role as Club Captain, Declan fosters team spirit and ensures that Steinitz continues its proud tradition of excellence and camaraderie. Balancing competitive play with mentorship, he exemplifies the values of leadership, sportsmanship, and commitment to the growth of chess in his community.

item.title: Furqaan Bowman
item.description: Furqaan Bowman is a dedicated youth chess player whose journey reflects both talent and resilience. His strongest performance came during the Junior League U16, where he achieved a tournament performance rating of 1630 — a clear sign of his ability to compete at a high level when focused and motivated. Like many young players, Furqaan has taken time away from the board, but his passion for the game remains undimmed. He enjoys the challenge chess brings, testing his creativity, focus, and problem-solving under pressure. Known for his calm presence and thoughtful approach to the game, Furqaan brings a maturity to the board that belies his years. As he continues his chess journey, Furqaan is looking to build on past achievements and rediscover his competitive rhythm. His return to active play signals not only unfinished business but also the promise of future growth in the sport he loves.

item.title: Glenn Willenberg
item.description: Glen I. Willenberg is a seasoned chess player and life-long member of Steinitz Chess Club. Throughout his chess career, Glen has participated in various tournaments, including the South African Closed Chess Championship 2024, where he competed in the Seniors category . Beyond individual competitions, Glen is actively involved in the chess community. As of 2025 he proudly represents his club A-team at the CTCF club league. Glen’s dedication to chess and his active participation in both competitive and community events highlight his commitment to the game and its development in South Africa.

item.title: Izaiah Solomon
item.description: Izaiah Solomon is a talented young chess player from South Africa, currently a Grade 10 learner at Curro Somerset West. He has demonstrated exceptional skill and leadership in the chess community. Achievements: Provincial Representation: In September 2025, Izaiah was selected to represent the Western Cape Boys Under-18 team at the Mzansi Interprovincial Youth Chess Championships (MIYCC), showcasing his prowess at the provincial level. Club Championship Success: In 2024, as a Grade 9 learner, Izaiah earned a silver medal at the Western Cape Club Championship, highlighting his competitive edge in regional tournaments. Team Leadership: Serving as captain, Izaiah led the Steinitz Chess Club’s Under-18 team to victory in the Cape Town Junior Chess League’s A Division in 2024, underscoring his leadership and teamwork abilities. Regional Championship Victory: In 2025, he won the inaugural Overberg Schools Chess Championship (OSAJCCC), demonstrating his dominance in regional competitions.

item.title: Jesse Palmer
item.description: Jesse Palmer is a promising young chess talent from Cape Town, South Africa. He holds the title of Arena International Master (AIM) and has achieved impressive FIDE ratings across all formats. Since 2024 he has since demonstrated remarkable improvement. He has participated in numerous tournaments, consistently achieving strong results. For instance, in the 2025 Bellville Rapid Tournament, he scored 6 points out of 6, showcasing his dominance in the rapid format. Beyond his individual accomplishments, Jesse is an active member of the chess community. He has represented his school, Curro Durbanville, in various competitions, contributing to their success. His dedication to the game and rapid progression have made him a notable figure among his peers.

item.title: Jody Roman
item.description: Jody Roman has always had a passion for chess. Through a chance interaction with one of Steinitz’s long-standing members, he was reintroduced to the game and welcomed into the close-knit Steinitz family. As a social player and adult improver, Jody has been eager to contribute—taking on the role of Team Captain for various development teams, competing more actively in local tournaments, and even stepping into an ExCo position at the club. Reflecting on his journey, Jody lives by the words of Wilhelm Steinitz: “Chess is not for timid souls.” The game brings both highs and lows, but for him, it is about taking the bull by the horns and enjoying the ride.

item.title: Kenneth Willenberg
item.description: Kenneth Sean “Kenny” Willenberg is a South African Candidate Master (CM), currently regarded as one of the country’s strongest players. A product of Steinitz Chess Club and the proud Willenberg chess-playing legacy, Kenny has built a reputation for consistent success in both national closed championships and local league competitions. Once crowned South African Under-20 Champion, he has made multiple appearances at the SA Closed Championship, firmly establishing himself as one of the nation’s leading players early in his career. Beyond his own competitive achievements, Kenny has dedicated himself to coaching and talent development, working through programs at Curro Durbanville and Reddam House Durbanville. His impact as a coach was most prominently seen at the 2025 Top Schools competition, where his Reddam U9 team not only placed first in their division but also swept all six board prizes—a rare and dominant feat. Balancing competitive strength with a passion for mentorship, Kenny continues to inspire both on and off the board, making him a highly respected figure in South African chess.

item.title: Lyndon Bouah
item.description: Dr. Lyndon Bouah is a distinguished figure in South African chess—both as a competitive veteran and as a scholar-administrator. Holding the title of Candidate Master, he has represented his nation at events including the 1992 and 1994 Chess Olympiads. In 2024, Bouah made a remarkable return to competitive play, emerging as co-champion in the Senior Section of the South African Closed Chess Championship, achieving an undefeated 8.5/11 alongside Dr. Shabier Bhawoodien. Off the board, Dr. Bouah is a committed researcher and author, notably publishing Reflection on Chess in the Rainbow Nation, a deeply personal and cultural exploration of chess in South Africa. He also serves as the Chief Director for Sport and Recreation in the Western Cape, blending his passion for chess with leadership in public service.

item.title: Mark Lewis
item.description: Mark Lewis is a seasoned chess coach and a founding member of Cape Town’s Steinitz Chess Club, established in 1976 when four high-school students in Bonteheuwel came together to form a club named after World Champion Wilhelm Steinitz. A respected leader in South African chess, Lewis is a former president of both the Steinitz Chess Club and the Cape Town Chess Federation (CTCF). Under his leadership, Steinitz grew into one of the strongest clubs in the country, winning national titles and nurturing top players from the Cape Flats. In addition to his administrative and coaching roles, Lewis remains active as a competitive player, highlighted by his victory at the 2022 South African Senior Championship, scoring 7.5 points. His lifelong dedication has left a lasting mark on South African chess.

item.title: Paul Khuphwathea
item.description: Paul C. Khuphwathea is a highly respected chess player and coach from Malawi, now making his mark in Cape Town, South Africa. A Candidate Master since 2016, he has represented his country with pride on the international stage, including appearances at the 2012 Chess Olympiad in Istanbul, Turkey, and again at the 42nd Olympiad in Baku, Azerbaijan, in 2016, where he faced some of the world’s strongest players. Beyond his own competitive success, Paul has devoted himself to the growth and development of young chess talent. A licensed FIDE Developmental Instructor (2011–2025), he now coaches full time at United Herzlia Schools and the German International School of Cape Town. His dynamic teaching style and deep love for the game have inspired countless students, helping them build not only chess skills but also confidence, discipline, and critical thinking. With his combination of international experience, coaching expertise, and passion for education, Paul continues to play a vital role in strengthening the chess culture of Cape Town and beyond.

item.title: Phillip Tjale
item.description: Phillipmaite Tjale learned how to play chess on a home-made set, much like the great Mikhail Botvinnik. This unique start sparked a deep appreciation for the Soviet-era chess players and a love for dynamic, attacking styles, with solid positional foundations. While his passion lies in aggressive play, his style is more a testament to the fundamentals: a solid, balanced approach that focuses on defensive soundness and capitalizing on his opponent’s errors.

His decision to join Steinitz came naturally: when he mentioned his move to a colleague, he was told without hesitation that Steinitz is the best club in the country — advice he gladly took to heart.

item.title: Roland Willenberg
item.description: Roland Willenberg is a veteran South African chess coach and one of the founding members of Steinitz. item.title: Romayo Page
item.description: Romayo Page’s journey in chess is a testament to dedication, mentorship, and community spirit. From the early days of competing with Boland A and B teams during the 1990s—sharing the stage with renowned players like Deon Pick and Kenny Solomon—Romayo’s love for the game was evident. Guided by the late Mr. Brown, a multifaceted mentor whose talents spanned authorship, songwriting, and chess, Romayo’s passion for the sport grew deeper with each passing year. As a leader, Romayo left a lasting mark on Western Cape Chess. Serving as Western Province Manager for Top Schools from 2009 to 2015, Romayo orchestrated a golden era for The Settlers High School Chess teams, who remained unbeaten for nine consecutive years—a feat made possible by the unwavering commitment of Steinitz coaches and a thriving school spirit. Romayo’s connection to the Willenberg family during his teaching tenure at The Settlers High School proved pivotal. This bond naturally led Romayo to join Steinitz Chess Club, where the sense of family and shared ambition continued to flourish.
